abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Cottage and
            Small Industries Project for Nepal was marginally
            unsatisfactory. The project only partially achieved its
            objectives, its impact on institutional development was
            negligible, sustainability is unlikely, and the performance
            of both the Bank and Borrower was less than satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            successor projects should not be launched before proper
            assessment of on-going similar projects. Second, the design
            of investment credits for CSI, especially in countries like
            Nepal with underdeveloped financial and industrial sectors
            and limited implementation capacity, should be kept simple
            with clear and focused objectives. Third, creating new
            agencies to bypass existing inefficient units often causes
            duplication and overlapping of activities. Fourth,
            innovative concepts, such as "project-based
            lending", should be introduced in a project only after
            that the essential ingredients required for successful
            implementation are in place. Fifth, the risks of CSI lending
            in a poor credit environment should have been minimized
            through an effective management information system in the
            PCIs. Sixth, key actions should have clear completion
            schedules and their compliance within the deadline should be
            strictly monitored. Finally, relying on studies alone in a
            small project such as CSI-II was not an effective way to
            encourage policy reform.
